sources.label: DVLA Neurological disorders: assessing fitness to drive

sz_type.title: What best describes the event?
sz_type.help: If it’s actually syncope/TLoC, use the syncope module. If it’s an epileptic seizure, continue here.

sz_risk_factor.title: Any underlying factor that may increase recurrence risk?
sz_risk_factor.help: This is the DVLA-style branching used in many UK summaries: ‘no factor’ → 6 months; ‘factor present’ → 12 months (Group 1).

sz_date.title: Date of the seizure (DD/MM/YYYY)
sz_date.help: We calculate time since the event to display the minimum stop-driving period remaining.

restrictionLogic.then: Must not drive for 6 months from the date of the seizure (Group 1), provided no higher-risk features apply.
restrictionLogic.else: Must not drive for 12 months from the date of the seizure (Group 1), where factors increase recurrence risk.

group2.restriction: Must not drive and must notify DVLA (Group 2 standards are significantly stricter and longer).

group1.restriction: Must not drive and must notify DVLA. Driving cessation is typically 12 months from most recent seizure unless a permitted seizure criteria applies (see DVLA appendices).

group2.restriction: Must not drive and must notify DVLA (Group 2 is stricter).
